markdownRemark.excerpt: Like a lot of people, when I finished my bachelors program, I had no real idea what I wanted to do. It was 2012 and the country was still starting to recover…
markdownRemark.html:
Like a lot of people, when I finished my bachelors program, I had no real idea what I wanted to do. It was 2012 and the country was still starting to recover from the real estate bubble popping, there weren’t a lot of opportunities out there. I did the normal job search and eventually landed a job as a project manager. This wasn’t necessarily my “dream job” but I had student loans to repay. So I took it.

I had no real idea how to work on building my career. I thought it was just a linear process, start as a junior project manager, find a more senior role and you make your way up that way. But I realized that it didn’t quite work like that. If I didn’t have an idea of what the next job I wanted was, I couldn’t work to build the necessary skills I would need to highlight to get that job. This led to a lot of frustration when I was ready to move on from this first role.

If I had spent time during those first few years seeking out feedback on areas I needed improvement, had honest conversations with people in positions that interested me and used that information to develop myself it would have made the job search a lot easier. When you narrow in on a particular role that interests you, you can make sure you have the skills required to excel in that role.

frontmatter.title: Career Planning
frontmatter.description: Looking at what skills you need to move into a new role is crucial to help you plan out a career.
